quote: If the freedom of speech is taken away then dumb and silent we may be led, like sheep to the slaughter.
author: Unknown

quote: The Constitution is the guide which I never will abandon.
author: Unknown

quote: There is nothing which can better deserve your patronage, than the promotion of science and literature. Knowledge is in every country the surest basis of public happiness.
author: Unknown

quote: Associate with men of good quality if you esteem your own reputation.
author: George Washington

quote: Laws made by common consent must not be trampled on by individuals.
author: Unknown

quote: Some day, following the example of the United States of America, there will be a United States of Europe.
author: Unknown

quote: Religion is as necessary to reason as reason is to religion. The one cannot exist without the other. author: Unknown

quote: It will be found an unjust and unwise jealousy to deprive a man of his natural liberty upon the supposition he may abuse it.
author: Unknown

quote: Nothing can be more hurtful to the service, than the neglect of discipline; for that discipline, more than numbers, gives one army the superiority over another.
author: Unknown

quote: Discipline is the soul of an army. It makes small numbers formidable; procures success to the weak, and esteem to all.
author: George Washington

author: Unknown

quote: Arbitrary power is most easily established on the ruins of liberty abused to licentiousness.
author: Unknown

quote: War – An act of violence whose object is to constrain the enemy, to accomplish our will.
author: Unknown

quote: A slender acquaintance with the world must convince every man that actions, not words, are the true criterion of the attachment of friends.
author: Unknown

quote: There can be no greater error than to expect, or calculate, upon real favors from nation to nation. It is an illusion which experience must cure, which a just pride ought to discard.
author: Unknown

quote: Worry is the interest paid by those who borrow trouble.
author: George Washington

quote: My observation is that whenever one person is found adequate to the discharge of a duty… it is worse executed by two persons, and scarcely done at all if three or more are employed therein.
author: Unknown

quote: I beg you be persuaded that no one would be more zealous than myself to establish effectual barriers against the horrors of spiritual tyranny, and every species of religious persecution.
author: Unknown

quote: I am persuaded, you will permit me to observe, that the path of true piety is so plain as to require but little political direction.
author: Unknown

quote: I know of no pursuit in which more real and important services can be rendered to any country than by improving its agriculture, its breed of useful animals, and other branches of a husbandman’s cares.
author: Unknown

quote: The Constitution which at any time exists, ’till changed by an explicit and authentic act of the whole People is sacredly obligatory upon all.
author: Unknown

quote: Guard against the impostures of pretended patriotism.
author: George Washington

quote: To form a new Government, requires infinite care, and unbounded attention; for if the foundation is badly laid the superstructure must be bad.
author: Unknown

quote: The tumultuous populace of large cities are ever to be dreaded. Their indiscriminate violence prostrates for the time all public authority, and its consequences are sometimes extensive and terrible.
author: Unknown

quote: The establishment of Civil and Religious Liberty was the Motive which induced me to the Field — the object is attained — and it now remains to be my earnest wish & prayer, that the Citizens of the United States could make a wise and virtuous use of the blessings placed before them.
author: Unknown

quote: But if we are to be told by a foreign power what we shall do, and what we shall not do, we have Independence yet to seek, and have contended hitherto for very little.
author: Unknown

quote: Gentlemen, you will permit me to put on my spectacles, for, I have grown not only gray, but almost blind in the service of my country.
author: Unknown

quote: It is better to offer no excuse than a bad one.
author: George Washington

quote: Government is not reason and it is not eloquence. It is force! Like fire it is a dangerous servant and a fearful master. Never for a moment should it be left to irresponsible action.
author: Unknown

quote: It should be the highest ambition of every American to extend his views beyond himself, and to bear in mind that his conduct will not only affect himself, his country, and his immediate posterity; but that its influence may be co-extensive with the world, and stamp political happiness or misery on ages yet unborn.
author: Unknown

quote: The Hand of providence has been so conspicuous in all this, that he must be worse than an infidel that lacks faith, and more than wicked, that has not gratitude enough to acknowledge his obligations.
author: Unknown

quote: I do not mean to exclude altogether the idea of patriotism. I know it exists, and I know it has done much in the present contest. author: Unknown

quote: The foundations of our national policy will be laid in the pure and immutable principles of private morality, and the preeminence of free government be exemplified by all the attributes which can win the affections of its citizens, and command the respect of the world.
author: Unknown

quote: It is better to be alone than in bad company.
author: George Washington

quote: The preservation of the sacred fire of liberty, and the destiny of the republican model of government, are justly considered deeply, perhaps as finally, staked on the experiment entrusted to the hands of the American people.
author: Unknown

quote: [Gambling] is the child of avarice, the brother of iniquity, and the father of mischief.
author: Unknown

quote: No country upon earth ever had it more in its power to attain these blessings than United America. author: Unknown

quote: Over grown military establishments are under any form of government inauspicious to liberty, and are to be regarded as particularly hostile to republican liberty.
author: Unknown

quote: I hope, some day or another, we shall become a storehouse and granary for the world.
author: Unknown

quote: To contract new debts is not the way to pay old ones.

quote: The time is near at hand which must determine whether Americans are to be free men or slaves.
author: Unknown

quote: Where is the security for property, for reputation, for life, if the sense of religious obligation deserts the oaths?
author: Unknown

quote: Let us raise a standard to which the wise and honest can repair; the rest is in the hands of God.
author: Unknown

quote: Citizens by birth or choice of a common country, that country has a right to concentrate your affections. The name of American, which belongs to you, in your national capacity, must always exalt the just pride of Patriotism, more than any appellation derived from local discriminations.

quote: I anticipate with pleasing expectations that retreat in which I promise myself to realize, without alloy, the sweet enjoyment of partaking, in the midst of my fellow citizens, the benign influence of good laws under a free government, the ever favorite object of my heart, and the happy reward, as I trust, of our mutual cares, labors, and dangers.
author: Unknown

quote: Observe good faith and justice toward all nations. Cultivate peace and harmony with all.
author: George Washington

quote: Jealousy, and local policy mix too much in all our public councils for the good government of the Union. In a words, the confederation appears to me to be little more than a shadow without the substance.
author: Unknown

quote: I wish from my soul that the legislature of this State could see the policy of a gradual Abolition of Slavery.
author: Unknown

quote: I go to the chair of government with feelings not unlike those of a culprit who is going to the place of his execution.
author: Unknown

quote: The value of liberty was thus enhanced in our estimation by the difficulty of its attainment, and the worth of characters appreciated by the trial of adversity.
author: Unknown

quote: Mankind, when left to themselves, are unfit for their own government.
author: Unknown

quote: Few people have the virtue to withstand the highest bidder.
author: George Washington

quote: We are either a United people, or we are not. If the former, let us, in all matters of general concern act as a nation, which have national objects to promote, and a national character to support. If we are not, let us no longer act a farce by pretending to it.

quote: When we assumed the Soldier, we did not lay aside the Citizen.
author: Unknown

quote: The Army (considering the irritable state it is in, its suffering and composition) is a dangerous instrument to play with.
author: Unknown

quote: Your love of liberty – your respect for the laws – your habits of industry – and your practice of the moral and religious obligations, are the strongest claims to national and individual happiness.
author: Unknown

quote: Democratical States must always feel before they can see: it is this that makes their Governments slow, but the people will be right at last.
author: Unknown

quote: Truth will ultimately prevail where there is pains to bring it to light.
author: George Washington

quote: The foundation of a great Empire is laid, and I please myself with a persuasion, that Providence will not leave its work imperfect.
author: Unknown

quote: Having now finished the work assigned me, I retire from the great theatre of Action; and bidding an Affectionate farewell to this August body under whose orders I have so long acted, I here offer my commission, and take my leave of all the employments of public life.
author: Unknown

quote: The liberty enjoyed by the people of these states of worshiping Almighty God agreeably to their conscience, is not only among the choicest of their blessings, but also of their rights.
author: Unknown

quote: It appears to me, then, little short of a miracle, that the Delegates from so many different States should unite in forming a system of national Government, so little liable to well founded objections.
author: Unknown

quote: In proportion as the structure of a government gives force to public opinion, it is essential that public opinion should be enlightened.
author: Unknown

quote: Let your heart feel for the afflictions and distress of everyone, and let your hand give in proportion to your purse.
author: George Washington

quote: ‘Tis our true policy to steer clear of permanent alliances with any portion of the foreign world.
author: Unknown

quote: No morn ever dawned more favorable than ours did; and no day was every more clouded than the present! Wisdom, and good examples are necessary at this time to rescue the political machine from the impending storm.
author: Unknown

quote: In our progress toward political happiness my station is new; and if I may use the expression, I walk on untrodden ground. There is scarcely any part of my conduct wch. may not hereafter be drawn into precedent.
author: Unknown

quote: [A] good moral character is the first essential in a man, and that the habits contracted at your age are generally indelible, and your conduct here may stamp your character through life. It is therefore highly important that you should endeavor not only to be learned but virtuous.
author: Unknown

quote: The propitious smiles of Heaven can never be expected on a nation that disregards the eternal rules of order and right, which Heaven itself has ordained.
author: Unknown

quote: Honesty will be found on every experiment, to be the best and only true policy; let us then as a Nation be just.

quote: Every post is honorable in which a man can serve his country.

quote: More permanent and genuine happiness is to be found in the sequestered walks of connubial life than in the giddy rounds of promiscuous pleasure.

quote: A people who are possessed of the spirit of commerce, who see and who will pursue their advantages may achieve almost anything.
author: Unknown

quote: A man’s intentions should be allowed in some respects to plead for his actions.

quote: I shall make it the most agreeable part of my duty to study merit, and reward the brave and deserving.
author: Unknown

quote: 99% of failures come from people who make excuses.

quote: No taxes can be devised which are not more or less inconvenient and unpleasant.
author: Unknown

quote: I hold the maxim no less applicable to public than to private affairs, that honesty is the best policy.

quote: Nothing is a greater stranger to my breast, or a sin that my soul more abhors, than that black and detestable one, ingratitude.

author: Unknown

quote: I was summoned by my country, whose voice I can never hear but with veneration and love.

quote: We must take human nature as we find it, perfection falls not to the share of mortals.

quote: There is a Destiny which has the control of our actions, not to be resisted by the strongest efforts of Human Nature.

quote: Perseverance and spirit have done wonders in all ages.

quote: Happiness and moral duty are inseparably connected.

quote: The harder the conflict, the greater the triumph.
author: Unknown

author: Unknown

author: Unknown

author: Unknown

quote: You think of George Washington, this man who was larger than life, and in some ways he was. But at the same time, he’s just a person.
author: Benjamin Walker

author: Robert Dallek

quote: George Washington understood that the Bible is the place where God’s records of right and wrong are kept.
author: Randall Terry

quote: George Washington participated as a vestryman in his local congregation, but that didn’t really imply any particular kind of religious belief. This was necessary in order to participate in the society.
author: Matthew Stewart
